snippet: The relationship between a priest and a nun gives rise to suspicion in a revival of Milan Stitt’s play “The Runner Stumbles,”at the ArcLight Theater.
abstract: Ken Jaworowski reviews revival of 1976 Milan Stitt play The Runner Stumbles, directed by Peter Zinn and starring Christopher Patrick Mullen at ArcLight Theater. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Sex and murder don't guarantee a successful play. But they sure don't hurt its chances. That's certainly true in ''The Runner Stumbles,'' a drama that surmounts more than a few problems to become quite an absorbing show. Set in 1911 and based loosely on real events, the story centers on Father Rivard (Christopher Patrick Mullen), a disheartened small-town priest who finds himself drawn to Sister Rita (Casandera M. J. Lollar), a new nun at his ailing parish. Their relationship becomes a source of gossip, and when Sister Rita is later found dead, Father Rivard is the prime suspect.

headline.main: A Forbidden Attraction Is Just the Beginning
